body: The UnknownSystemError means something between OS X and Electron has interrupted the system call, it could be virus scanner or firewall software.

Hi, I don't use virus scanner or firewall software.
Problem starts with electron 0.22.0 (Upgrade to Chrome 41)

Getting this error as well on OS X Mavericks.
I have no virus scanners or firewalls installed.

Same error here on OS X 10.9.4.
Runs fine on Ubuntu 15.04
@zcbenz ping
Seems like this happens for me if if execute a child process from the renderer thread. Executing it from the browser process still raises the error, but can be ignored somehow...
I'm getting this too. @tomashanacek did you come across any solution yet?

In my case, we were using es6 in the webview via `require( "babel/register" )`.  After transpiling back to es5 at build and removing the `require( "babel/register" )` I no longer see the `uv_pipe_open` error and everything seems to work fine!

So I'm not sure exactly what in babel is causing the error but at least there is an easy way to sidestep it in this case.
@zcbenz I'm seeing this issue without any virus scanner or firewall present.

I'm seeing this error when something tries to access the `process.stdout` property. It seems like node is attempting to create the stream with the file descriptor `1` and fails. In my case it's mocha attempting to see if we have a stdout and if it's a TTY.

Was this closed in error?  I'm hitting this problem with electron 0.30.4 on OSX Mavericks.  I'm using babel/register like joshwnj mentions so that's probably the issue, but this definitely seems like a valid issue or something broken in electron.

@tdicola In my case something was trying to access `process.stdout`, which isn't currently accessible in Electron. @zcbenz I wonder if it makes sense to guard against this case in some way by directing `process.stdout` to the console?

I'm reopening this since people are seeing this for various reasons.

@nathansobo Were you using OS X 10.9? The process.stdout is guarded under Windows, but seeing it on OS X is definitely not normal. I'm wondering whether it is a bug of OS X 10.9.
I was on 10.8 when I saw it but have since upgraded. I can try to reproduce on 10.9.

For what it's worth my issue was the same as joshwnj mentioned, using babel's register module in a web process causes the failure on OSX.  The workaround is to just transpile my ES6 & JSX code ahead of time to ES5 and remove the bable register usage.

I'm on 10.10.5 and started getting this same error after upgrading to electron 0.31.x. I'm also using ionic framework.

``` bash
[92344:0901/210453:INFO:CONSOLE(21157)] "Error: UnknownSystemError: Unknown system error, uv_pipe_open
    at Error (native)
    at new Socket (net.js:129:18)
    at createWritableStdioStream (node.js:601:18)
    at process.stdout (node.js:627:16)
    at /home/app/node_modules/chalk/node_modules/supports-color/index.js:29:13
    at Object.<anonymous> (/home/app/node_modules/chalk/node_modules/supports-color/index.js:50:3)
    at Module._compile (module.js:430:26)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:448:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:355:32)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:310:12)", source: file:///home/app/gui/bower_components/ionic/release/js/ionic.bundle.js (21157)
```

Looks like in my case, [chalk](https://www.npmjs.com/package/chalk) module, required from with in factory(), is causing this issue with electron 0.31.x

This was never an issue with electron 0.30.x for me.

@zcbenz ping. would be great to get some reply on the little repro I did. we typically adopt latest electron early in our milestones to get some good test coverage, but with this issue we are currently blocked on Mac.
I've hopefully patched this in Chalk, which seems to be where most of these errors show up

For those of you seeing this with Chalk-enabled packages, have you tried passing `--no-color` to the electron process?

Regardless, a patch version has been released, `3.1.1`.

@paulcbetts I believe this is just a workaround. I would have preferred an actual fix in electron / iojs, so i could generate colored console logs, like i was with electron 0.30.5 or 0.30.6
![screen shot 2015-09-02 at 12 33 15 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1380334/9642051/e40c6f3a-516e-11e5-977c-2cc7f00828bd.png)

I use [`winstonjs`](https://github.com/winstonjs/winston) that also has the same issue. Unfortunately, this module depends on [`colors`](https://github.com/Marak/colors.js) module that uses a [copy of `supports-color`](https://github.com/Marak/colors.js/blob/master/lib/system/supports-colors.js) code, instead of declaring it as dependency in its package.json. I'm not sure how many more modules have used a copy of `supports-color`. Hence, it is difficult to make workarounds in all those modules.
@ssreekanth @bpasero Thanks for your demos, I can reproduce them and they really helped a lot.

Seems that renderer process has inherited the stdout/stderr from parent process, and the type of stdout should be `TTY`, however Node.js mistakenly thought stdout's type was `pipe` in the renderer process, thus called wrong method for stdout.
@zcbenz is that a fix within electron, then?

@zcbenz glad to know that the demo code helped you in identifying the root cause of the issue.

Once a fix is provided in electron for this issue, we should revert the [workaround](https://github.com/chalk/supports-color/issues/30) made by @paulcbetts in `supports-color` module.
`process.type` isn't standard, and I'd be reluctant to keep the workaround in in the event a fix is made.

@paulcbetts, I would not keep the workaround either. Unless it is really an issue with `supports-color`, we should not make any change in there. If the issue is introduced in X module and not in `chalk`/`supports-color`, then it should be fixed in that particular X module. We should be glad that this workaround wasn't there earlier, otherwise we would have never unearthed this particular issue easily. 

Moreover, I was generating colored console logs from renderer processes. I would not like to loose that functionality.

> process.type isn't standard, and I'd be reluctant to keep the workaround in in the event a fix is made.

Well I mean, that's the idea - you're using it both to detect the presence of Electron, and whether you're in the Renderer process (i.e. where your console.log statements are ideally going to Devtools)

I'm still sketchy about a permanent workaround for this on Chalk's end. I agree it probably hits most of those using ANSI styles but at the same time it's not something that really belongs in chalk.

That being said, it appears the problem is being narrowed down on electron's end. :+1:

> I'm still sketchy about a permanent workaround for this on Chalk's end. I agree it probably hits most of those using ANSI styles but at the same time it's not something that really belongs in chalk.

I mean, at the end of the day, Electron is a special case for writing terminal output, so it's worth considering handling that case explicitly. While we definitely want to at minimum make sure it's not taking down Electron instances, it'd be cool for Chalk to possibly do stuff in the future like write styled output to DevTools a-la https://plus.google.com/+AddyOsmani/posts/TanDFKEN9Kn
Keep in mind chalk isn't necessarily the place for that kind of stuff, though.
@zcbenz was this resolved on Electron's side?
@Qix- Yeah.
@sindresorhus are we go for removing the workaround from our end?
@Qix- I think the check is still valid though, as Electron users wouldn't want colors.

According to [this](https://github.com/atom/electron/issues/1647#issuecomment-137222279), Electron did support color output in previous versions (e.g. v0.30.5). If that's true, then I think the work around in `supports-color` should be removed.
I would have to agree. Can someone from the Electron team confirm? I don't know enough about it.
Now that Electron fixed this issue, we should remove the workaround from `supports-color`
